Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Undergraduate Chemical Education Through Contextualized Organic Laboratories

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The focus of this project is to develop, implement and evaluate interdisciplinary science education materials, contextualized around the quest for drug discovery to treat neglected diseases. In order to solve this intellectual challenge, students are trained in chemical synthesis, computational analysis and biological evaluation through problem solving in each of these core scientific disciplines. As part of their course work, students gain general literacy regarding the application of science to solving important humanitarian problems, learn about the drug discovery process, use integrated STEM skills, and participate in national and international student and teacher collaborations. Independent professional assessment is part of the project design. Intellectual merit includes development of educational materials that will enable students to learn about the drug discovery process and perform significant research with no predetermined outcome during their undergraduate education. Broader impacts include the self-contained modules of lectures and labs, produced to achieve a readily disseminated, contextualized, multidisciplinary science laboratory experience that are simple, reproducible and inexpensive.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Distributed Drug Discovery (D3) program seeks to motivate and empower students worldwide to learn and apply interdisciplinary science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) knowledge and research skills. D3 connects students to challenges with global humanitarian implications – the discovery of drugs to treat neglected/orphan diseases. Education is carried out in critical STEM disciplines: synthesis, computational analysis and biological screening. This NSF-TUES grant has enabled the development and implementation of many tools required to fulfill D3’s vision for transforming undergraduate STEM education.  Its broader impact comes from addressing national calls to integrate the scientific process in early undergraduate laboratory courses, and to replace standard laboratory courses with discovery based research courses (1,2).

Continued adaptation of current D3 chemistry procedures has allowed second semester organic laboratory students at IUPUI and schools nationally and internationally to synthesize hundreds of new biomimetic molecules as candidates for drug discovery. The simple, inexpensive D3 Bill-Board equipment now made generally available permits each individual student (or student team) to carry out multiple, manual solid-phase syntheses. Six reactions are conducted simultaneously in fritted-glass reaction vessels organized in a simple 2x3 grid for combinatorial reaction sequences.  The essential steps of solid-phase synthesis (reaction and washing cycles, followed by final cleavage and product collection) are conveniently and effectively carried out. One Bill-Board position, replicated by all students, is reserved for a control synthesis (characteristic of a standard lab).

New, well-documented, D3 synthetic procedures extend the scope of molecules accessible for student synthesis and testing. Audio-visuals (20-30 minutes long) have been developed covering topics such as drug discovery (process/need), combinatorial chemistry (in nature and organic chemistry), solid-phase synthesis (peptides/organic molecules), and synthetic chemistry (synthetic schemes, reaction mechanisms). During this grant period, the program’s vision and content has been presented in oral and poster presentations at National American Chemical Society meetings and invited lectures at schools nationally and internationally. Outcomes testifying to both the educational and authentic research aspects of D3 have been presented in well respected peer-reviewed journals (Journal of Chemical Education and Journal of Organic Chemistry). These presentations have multiple students as co-authors, documenting the significant involvement of undergraduates in this work and the impact on their education.

Extensive national and international educational collaborations were developed through our International Distributed Drug Discovery workshop (2013) and Biennial Conference on Chemical Education (BCCE) presentations and workshop (2014). The educational potential of the D3 program is validated by the number of schools either currently participating in this effort or proposing future participation after learning about it through these meetings and presentations. Students from abroad have obtained independent funding to do internships at IUPUI and learn D3 chemistry.

The most recent advance, facilitated by NSF funding, has been the development of our first coupled D3 chemistry/biology labs. Two biological assays have been developed – the classic Kirby-Bauer disc plate assay, and inhibition of biofilm formation by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. They meet the D3 undergraduate laboratory criteria of simplicity, relevance, safety, reproducibility and low expense. They are conducted by beginning biology and microbiology students.
